  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang
 It features two different but similar designs on each half of the batik. The left side of the kain panjang features roses
 with a dense green foliage border along the left and bottom. The right side of the kain panjang features bunches of orchids. Butterflies are interspersed amongst the flowers.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The main floral motif on one side consists of bunches of orchids while roses embellish the other side.  The entire design is set again a white ground with butterflies interspersed among the bouquets.  A green and white border of filler motifs occupy one half of the kain panjang.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang, It features two different but similar designs on each half of the batik. The left side of the kain panjang features roses, with a dense green foliage border along the left and bottom. The right side of the kain panjang features bunches of orchids. Butterflies are interspersed amongst the flowers.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The main floral motif on one side consists of bunches of orchids while roses embellish the other side.  The entire design is set again a white ground with butterflies interspersed among the bouquets.  A green and white border of filler motifs occupy one half of the kain panjang.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.
